anchor.surface_text: on charges under sections 366 and 143 of the Indian Penal Code and each of them was convicted under both the sections and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for five years under section 366

The provisions of article 14 of the Constitution have come up for discussion before this Court in a number of cases., namely, Chiranjit Lal Chowdhuri v. The Union of India 1 , The State of Bombay v. F. N. Balsara 2 , The State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar 3

It is now well-established that while article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely, i that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped togetber from others left out of the group and ii that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to uphold Section 30 CrPC based on geographical/territorial classification for administrative convenience in backward areas

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: hing companytained in section 28 or section 29. Therefore, the provisions of section 28 and the second schedule must give way to the provisions of sec

anchor.surface_text: that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question. The classification may be founded on different bases namely, geographical, or according to objects or occupations or the like. What is necessary is that there must be a nexus between the basis of classification and the object of the Act under consideration.

concepts.interpretation: Nexus found in territorial needs like distance to sessions court, witness inconvenience, juror availability

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 of the Code of Criminal Procedure which is to be found in Chapter III which deals with Powers of Courts reads as follows- Subject to the other provisions of this Code, any offence under the Indian Penal Code may be tried- a by the High Court, or b by the Court of Session, or c by any other Court by which such offence is shown in the eighth column of the second schedule to be triable.

concepts.interpretation: Subject to other provisions including Section 30; lists courts competent to try offences

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 puts a limit to the power of punishment of a section 30 Magistrate in terms following- The Court of a Magistrate, specially empowered under section 30, may pass any sentence authorised by law, except a sentence of death or of transportation for a term exceeding seven years or imprisonment for a term exceeding seven years.

concepts.interpretation: Limits sentencing power of Section 30 Magistrates

anchor.surface_text: If the section 30 Magistrate after recording the evidence and before framing a charge feels that in the facts and circumstances of the case the maximum sentence which he can inflict will not meet the ends of justice he may, instead of disposing of the case himself, act under section 347 and commit the accused to the Court of Session.

concepts.interpretation: Allows Section 30 Magistrate to commit to Sessions Court if justice requires higher punishment

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: here is an obvious classification on which this section is based, namely, that such power may be companyferred on specified Magistrates in certain loc

concepts.unlisted_description: Commitment to Sessions on inadequacy of punishment

anchor.surface_text: Such Magistrate after perusing the challan and other relevant papers may, if he thinks that the ends of justice will be met if the case is tried by a section 30 Magistrate, submit the case to the District Magistrate with his own recommendations for such action as the latter may think fit to take under section 528 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

concepts.interpretation: Allows District Magistrate to withdraw/transfer case to Section 30 Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: He may consider that in the facts and circumstances of the case disclosed in the evidence the ends of justice require that the accused person should be committed to the Court of Session and in that event he will proceed to frame a charge and follow the provisions of sections 210 to 213.

concepts.interpretation: Discharge or commitment procedures in warrant cases

arguments.claim: There had been an infraction of the fundamental rights guaranteed to the appellants under article 14 of the Constitution of India because the appellants had been tried by a section 30 Magistrate and not by a Court of Session.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate appearing in support of the appeal contends before us, as was done before the High Court, that there had been an infraction of the fundamental rights guaranteed to the appellants under article 14 of the Constitution of India. The complaint is that the appellants had been tried by a section 30 Magistrate

court_response_anchor.surface_text: entional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants by the Sab-Divisional Magistrate or the District Magistrate or the section 30 Magistra

arguments.court_reasoning: No discrimination as section 30 creates additional court based on reasonable territorial classification with rational nexus; judicial safeguards prevent abuse; no evidence of purposeful discrimination

arguments.claim: Trial before Sessions Judge is more advantageous to accused than trial before section 30 Magistrate under warrant procedure due to commitment proceedings and aid of jury or assessors.

anchor.surface_text: A section 30 Magistrate is enjoined by that section to try the case brought before him as a Magistrate and accordingly in cases like the present case he will follow the warrant procedure which is different from the procedure followed by a Court of Session. The substance of the grievance is that a trial before the Sessions Judge is much more advantageous to the accused person in that he gets the benefit of the commitment proceedings before a Magistrate and then a trial before the Sessions Judge with the aid of the jury or assessors.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: entional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants by the Sab-Divisional Magistrate or the District Magistrate or the section 30 Magistra

arguments.court_reasoning: Apparent discrimination justified by reasonable classification and procedural safeguards allowing commitment or transfer as needed

arguments.claim: The impugned section did not bring about any discrimination or inequality between persons similarly circumstanced and consequently did not offend the equal protection clause of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: S. K. Das, J., took the view that the impugned section did not bring about any discrimination or inequality between persons similarly circumstanced and consequently did not offend the equal protection clause of the Constitution, while C. P. Sinha, J.,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: entional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants by the Sab-Divisional Magistrate or the District Magistrate or the section 30 Magistra

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees on facts and circumstances

court_response_anchor.surface_text: entional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants by the Sab-Divisional Magistrate or the District Magistrate or the section 30 Magistra

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court disagrees, finds no infringement

arguments.claim: Section 30 did not violate the inhibition of article 14.

anchor.surface_text: who in agreement with S. K. Das, J., held that section 30 did not violate the inhibition of article 14. The learned Chief Justice upheld the conviction but reduced the sentence.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: entional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants by the Sab-Divisional Magistrate or the District Magistrate or the section 30 Magistra

arguments.claim: Article 14 forbids class legislation but does not forbid reasonable classification if founded on intelligible differentia distinguishing grouped persons and that differentia has rational relation to object of statute.

anchor.surface_text: It is now well-established that while article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely, i that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped togetber from others left out of the group and ii that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

arguments.claim: Classification under section 30 may be founded on geographical or territorial basis as needs vary from place to place.

anchor.surface_text: The classification may be founded on different bases namely, geographical, or according to objects or occupations or the like. What is necessary is that there must be a nexus between the basis of classification and the object of the Act under consideration. ... Section 30, however, empowers the State Government in certain areas to invest the District Magistrate or any Magistrate of the first class with power to try as a Magistrate all offences not punishable with death.

arguments.claim: Section 28 is subject to other provisions including section 30; section 30 operates notwithstanding sections 28 or 29, creating an additional court for offences not punishable with death.

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 of the Code of Criminal Procedure which is to be found in Chapter III which deals with Powers of Courts reads as follows- Subject to the other provisions of this Code... Section 30, as it now stands, provides- ... notwithstanding anything contained in section 28 or section 29... Section 34 puts a limit to the power of punishment...

arguments.claim: There is no discrimination in section 30 itself as it authorizes investment of power in specified areas only; risk of trial by section 30 Magistrate falls alike on all committing such offences.

anchor.surface_text: There is an obvious classification on which this section is based, namely, that such power may be conferred on specified Magistrates in certain localities only... If the State invests any Magistrate with powers under section 30 anybody who commits any offence not punishable with death and triable by a Court of Session under section 28 read with the second schedule is also liable to be tried by the section 30 Magistrate. The risk of such liability falls alike upon all persons committing such an offence. Therefore, there is no discrimination in the section itself.

arguments.claim: Territorial classification under section 30 reasonable due to distance to Sessions Court, witness inconvenience, difficulty finding jurors in backward areas.

anchor.surface_text: S. K. Das, J., and the learned Chief Justice have in their respective judgments referred to certain circumstances, e.g. the distance between the place of occurrence and the headquarters where the Court of Session functions at considerable intervals, the inconvenience of bringing up witnesses from the interior, the difficulty of finding in the backward or out of the way places sufficient number of suitable persons to act as jurors or assessors, all of which make this classification quite a reasonable one.

arguments.claim: Even if law fair on face, discriminatory administration by public authority with evil eye and unequal hand violates equal protection; police may choose to send cases selectively to section 30 Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants, however, contends, on the strength of the decision of the Supreme Court of America in Yick Wo v. Hopkins that though a law be fair on its face and impartial in operation, yet, if it is administered by public authority with an evil eye and an unequal hand so as practically to make illegal discrimination between persons in similar circumstances materially to their rights, the denial of equal justice is still within the prohibition of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion 210. He may companysider that in the facts and circumstances of the case disclosed in the evidence the ends of justice require that the accused p

arguments.court_reasoning: Judicial discretion at multiple stages (ss.347,209,528 CrPC) prevents whim of police; no evidence of intentional purposeful discrimination in this case

arguments.claim: Section 30 Magistrate not bound to try case; may commit to Sessions under s.347 if punishment inadequate; decision by judicial discretion, not executive.

anchor.surface_text: When a case under section 366... is put up before a section 30 Magistrate... If the section 30 Magistrate after recording the evidence and before framing a charge feels that... the maximum sentence which he can inflict will not meet the ends of justice he may... act under section 347 and commit the accused to the Court of Session. Here... decided according to the discretion judicially exercised by the section 30 Magistrate himself.

arguments.claim: Non-section 30 Magistrate may recommend transfer to section 30 Mag under s.528 or commit to Sessions under ss.209-213 based on judicial discretion.

anchor.surface_text: Take the case of another person accused... sent up by the police to a Magistrate who is not empowered under section 30. Such Magistrate... may... submit the case to the District Magistrate... under section 528... Or... under section 209 or section 210... frame a charge and follow... sections 210 to 213...

arguments.claim: Ultimate decision on forum depends on proper exercise of judicial discretion by Magistrate concerned, not whim of police or executive; no capricious discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that the ultimate decision as to whether a person charged under section 366 should be tried by the Court of Session or by a section 30 Magistrate does not depend merely on the whim or idiosyncrasies of the police or the executive Government but depends ultimately on the proper exercise of judicial discretion by the Magistrate concerned.

arguments.claim: No suggestion of intentional or purposeful discrimination against appellants at any stage; judicial discretion not arbitrary, subject to revision by superior courts.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at once that in the present case there is no suggestion whatever that there has been at any stage any intentional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants... Further, the discretion of judicial officers is not arbitrary and the law provides for revision by superior Courts of orders passed by the Subordinate Courts.

holdings.text: hold that no case of infringement of fundamental right under Article 14 has been made out

anchor.surface_text: On the facts and circumstances of this case we find ourselves in agreement with S. K. Das, J., and Reuben, C. J., and hold that no case of infringement of fundamental right under Article 14 has been made out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court majority; Section 30 CrPC upheld under reasonable classification doctrine as territorial basis has rational nexus to administrative needs; judicial safeguards at ss. 347, 209, 528 CrPC prevent abuse; no evidence of discriminatory enforcement

holdings.text: article 14 condemns discrimination not only by a substantive law but also by a law of procedure

anchor.surface_text: It is also well established by the decisions of this Court that article 14 condemns discrimination not only by a substantive law but also by a law of procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows prior Supreme Court precedents; applies equality guarantee to procedural laws like CrPC s.30

holdings.text: the provisions of section 28 and the second schedule must give way to the provisions of section 30

anchor.surface_text: Further, the text of section 30 itself quite clearly says that its provisions will operate notwithstanding anything contained in section 28 or section 29.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: s.30 expressly operates 'notwithstanding' ss.28/29; s.28 subject to other Code provisions; creates additional forum

holdings.text: the effect of the exercise of authority by the State Government under section 30 is, as it were, to add in the 8th column of the second schedule the Magistrate so empowered as a Court before whom all offences not punishable with death will also be triable

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the State Government investing the District Magistrate or any Magistrate of the first class with power under section 30 is to bring into being an additional court in which all offences not punishable with death become triable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory construction: s.30 empowers additional magistrates without excluding sessions courts

holdings.text: There is an obvious classification on which this section is based, namely, that such power may be conferred on specified Magistrates in certain localities only... all of which make this classification quite a reasonable one

anchor.surface_text: There is an obvious classification on which this section is based, namely, that such power may be conferred on specified Magistrates in certain localities only and in respect of some offences only, namely, all offences other than those punishable with death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Territorial/geographical classification intelligible (specified areas); rational nexus to object (distance to sessions HQ, witness/juror issues in backward places)

holdings.text: there is no discrimination in the section itself

anchor.surface_text: The risk of such liability falls alike upon all persons committing such an offence. Therefore, there is no discrimination in the section itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equal application: any offender in empowered area equally liable to s.30 magistrate trial

holdings.text: the ultimate decision as to whether a person charged under section 366 should be tried by the Court of Session or by a section 30 Magistrate does not depend merely on the whim or idiosyncrasies of the police or the executive Government but depends ultimately on the proper exercise of judicial discretion by the Magistrate concerned

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that the ultimate decision as to whether a person charged under section 366 should be tried by the Court of Session or by a section 30 Magistrate does not depend merely on the whim or idiosyncrasies of the police or the executive Government but depends

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multiple judicial checkpoints (ss.347,209/210,528 CrPC) ensure forum choice by judicial, not executive/police, discretion

holdings.text: in the present case there is no suggestion whatever that there has been at any stage any intentional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at once that in the present case there is no suggestion whatever that there has been at any stage any intentional or purposeful discrimination as against the appellants by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of 'evil eye/unequal hand' discriminatory administration; judicial orders revisable
